prompt: A 62-year-old right-hand dominant male presents with 3 months of progressive right shoulder pain. The pain is located over the lateral shoulder and worsens at night, often waking him from sleep. He has difficulty reaching overhead and behind his back. He denies any trauma but works as a painter. On examination, there is weakness with resisted abduction and external rotation. What is the likely diagnosis, differential diagnoses, and recommended evaluation?

specific_considerations: Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy/Impingement Syndrome - inflammation and degeneration of tendons
Rotator Cuff Tear - partial or full-thickness, likely involving supraspinatus and/or infraspinatus

patient_factors.occupation: Painter - repetitive overhead work is risk factor
patient_factors.dominant_hand: Right - affected side matches dominant hand use

symptom_analysis: Lateral shoulder pain - classic location for rotator cuff pathology
Night pain waking from sleep - associated with rotator cuff tears/inflammation
Difficulty overhead/behind back - functional limitation consistent with cuff issues
No trauma - suggests degenerative or overuse etiology
Progressive over 3 months - typical for degenerative tears

differential_diagnoses.notes: Progressive pain and stiffness, limited active AND passive ROM. Primary feature is stiffness.
Degenerative joint changes, deep aching pain worse with activity.
Often occurs with impingement, significant weakness less common without cuff tear.
Pain at top of shoulder, worse with cross-body adduction.
Nerve root compression, usually with neck pain, numbness, tingling in dermatomal pattern.
Anterior shoulder pain, weakness with elbow flexion/supination.

history: Ask about passive range of motion

physical_examination.range_of_motion: Active and passive ROM in all planes - flexion, abduction, internal/external rotation
physical_examination.strength_testing: Manual muscle testing of supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis
physical_examination.palpation: Tenderness over rotator cuff tendons, subacromial space, AC joint, biceps tendon

xrays.purpose: Rule out osteoarthritis, fractures, acromial spurs

mri.purpose: Gold standard for soft tissue evaluation

ultrasound.notes: Operator-dependent, may be less sensitive for deeper structures

response.management_considerations: Treatment decision (conservative vs surgical) depends on tear size, patient factors, and functional demands
response.disclaimer: This comprehensive approach will help pinpoint the exact nature and severity of the shoulder pathology, guiding appropriate treatment.
